hero.title: THE SOCIOSCOPE
hero.subtitle: Seeing How Social Change Takes Shape

vision.title: A Social Microscope on Food Systems Change
vision.statement1: Through large scale data collection around the world and LLM-driven research, the Socioscope analyses how behaviours, norms, and practices evolve within sustainable food transitions.
vision.statement2: We're building a systemic way to help make complex social patterns measurable, comparable, and understandable.

card1.title: Data
card1.description: Sophisticated on-the-ground data collection across 35+ countries, capturing not just what initiatives do, but how they transform economic, ecological, cultural and governance ecosystems.
card1.description2: Our researchers conduct ethnographic fieldwork, semi-structured qualitative interviews, and participatory observation to build the most comprehensive data set of food system transformations.

card2.title: Technology
card2.description: Establishing an LLM-driven research methodology that can process qualitative data at large scale while preserving contextual nuance and cultural specificity.
card2.description2: Built on Sleipnir, our analytical framework enables pattern recognition across hundreds of cases, finding what traditional methods may miss.

card3.title: Analysis
card3.description: Developing new frameworks and pathways to understand food systems transformation across sectors and contexts examining economic, political and cultural dimensions.
card3.description2: Unpacking how stakeholders work together, the motivations and values that incentivize them, and key challenges; a layered approach to mapping how transformation happens.

microscope.title: A Social Microscope on Food Systems Change
microscope.description1: Through large scale data collection around the world and LLM-driven research, the Socioscope analyses how behaviours, norms, and practices evolve within sustainable food transitions.
microscope.description2: We're building a systemic way to help make complex social patterns measurable, comparable, and understandable.

breakthroughs.title: Scientific Breakthroughs
breakthroughs.subtitle: We're not just collecting stories. We're discovering the fundamental laws of how societies transform themselves.

card1.title: Universal Patterns Across Cultures
card1.description: Despite vast cultural differences, we're finding common mechanisms in how communities achieve sustainable changeâ€”from rural Kenya to urban Tokyo.

card2.title: Cross-Cultural Pattern Recognition
card2.description: We can now compare how sustainability works in a village facing hunger versus a city drowning in waste versus a community rebuilding after crisisâ€”and discover universal mechanisms beneath surface differences.

card3.title: From Micro to Macro
card3.description: For the first time, we can rigorously trace the path from individual choices to community practices to systemic transformation. Social science's equivalent of physics' scaling laws.

card4.title: A Generalizable Method
card4.description: We start with food as our "model organism," but this methodology can be applied to any domain of social changeâ€”from climate action to healthcare to democracy itself.

hero.title: About The Socioscope
hero.subtitle: Understanding what truly drives sustainable change

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.paragraph1: The Socioscope is a transformative qualitative research project that maps how behaviours, norms, and communities influence the transition toward sustainable food systems.
mission.paragraph2: The Socioscope serves as a comprehensive observatory of these efforts, making knowledge accessible to researchers, policymakers, and practitioners worldwide. Equally important is shining a light on local initiatives that lead change on the ground and drive the shift toward a more sustainable food system.

whatWeDo.title: What We Do
whatWeDo.paragraph1: The Socioscope explores how sustainable change happens on the ground, with a focus on food systems. We document local solutions, speak with practitioners, and analyse insights using AI to reveal the patterns behind impactful innovation.
whatWeDo.paragraph2: Through systematic research and community engagement, we identify, document, and analyze initiatives that embody sustainable transformation principles. Our database includes grassroots movements, community-led projects, participatory governance experiments, and collaborative problem-solving platforms from every continent.

methodology.title: Our Methodology
methodology.subtitle: Combining academic rigor with participatory research approaches

step1.title: Identification
step1.desc: Through network analysis, expert recommendations, and community nominations, we identify initiatives that demonstrate sustainable transformation principles.

step2.title: Documentation
step2.desc: Our trained interviewers conduct in-depth conversations with initiative leaders and participants, capturing rich qualitative data about local food systems.

step3.title: Analysis
step3.desc: Using AI-powered mixed methods, we analyze patterns across initiatives, identifying success factors, challenges, and transferable insights.

step4.title: Dissemination
step4.desc: We share findings through publications, social media, and community engagement, ensuring knowledge reaches diverse audiences worldwide.

global.title: Global Perspective
global.desc: We recognize that sustainable change manifests differently across cultures and contexts, and we value this diversity as a source of learning and innovation.

collaboration.title: Collaboration
collaboration.desc: We practice what we study, working collaboratively with research partners, community members, and initiatives to co-create knowledge about food systems.

open.title: Openness
open.desc: We believe knowledge should be freely accessible. Our database is open to all, supporting the global commons of sustainability research.

ethical.title: Ethical Practice
ethical.desc: We conduct research with integrity, respecting participant autonomy, maintaining confidentiality, and ensuring our work benefits the communities we study.

cta.title: Get Involved
cta.description: Whether you're a researcher, practitioner, or community organizer, there are many ways to engage with The Socioscope and contribute to our shared understanding of sustainable food systems.
